headline: Finding Love in the Wilderness
text: Anisha Chopra was living in New York and had never been camping when she decided in 2015 that she was wanted to spend a night in the wilderness, and so she asked for some guidance.

headline: Is Your Crush on OkCupid Telling You the Truth?
text: How much dishonesty do you expect when interacting with people online?

headline: When Best Friends Become More
text: Kirin Gupta wasn’t yet in love with Irfan Mahmud when she entered his number into her cellphone under the label “Future Husband.”

headline: High School Sweethearts Together for Good
text: Kendall Anne Michaelis and Michael Joseph Harrell started out as high school sweethearts. They met and began dating in 2005 when he was a junior and she was a sophomore at Wheeler High School in Marietta, Ga. And like many high school sweethearts, Ms. Michaelis, 31, and Mr. Harrell, 32, were off again on again through college. Afterward, she headed for New York City, and he went the University of Georgia School of Law.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, August 6, 2021
text: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Dancing His Way Into Her Heart
text: Crested Butte Mountain in Colorado is majestic. That would be reason enough to get married in its presence. But for Abigail Berger and David Frum, getting married there was a sacred celebration.

headline: The Good and Bad News About the Delta Variant
text: “The war has changed.” That’s what the leaked C.D.C. document says about the way the Delta variant has upended our coronavirus policies. Delta is astonishingly contagious. It can generate 1,000 times the viral load of the original coronavirus strain, and it spreads with the ease of chickenpox. The vaccinated can no longer assume immunity. The unvaccinated are at more risk than ever. Masks are back. New York City is essentially imposing a vaccine mandate.

headline: A Ride of a Lifetime to a Catskills Retreat
text: Florence Christina Johnson met Dr. Nima Yazdanpanah in September 2019 when she got a ride with him arranged by the organizer of a weekend spiritual retreat in New York’s Catskills region.

headline: The Olympics Are All Fun, No Games on TikTok
text: Olympians are the world’s most impressive athletes. Watching them show off their superhuman strength, endurance and form, it’s easy to forget that many of them are not just mortals but teens and 20-somethings, effectively living in dorms, their emotions and hormones swiveling and swerving as they vie for the ultimate honors in sports.

headline: Finding Romance After Ditching the ‘Check-the-Box Approach’
text: Jane Jeong and Byron Hsu have always managed to individually achieve what they have set their minds to. But they needed the other to learn what it truly means to love.

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Say Goodbye to New York City?
text: Nine months after Julie Fishkin moved from New York City to Portland, Ore., she was still following the Brooklyn-based website, Park Slope Parents. A few weeks ago, at something of an emotional nadir, she posted on an active thread called “PSP BK Stay or Go” — “Honestly for me, this has been like grieving a major loss.”

headline: Leaping Into Love and a Life of Spontaneity
text: When Jordan Culbreath, an accomplished running back for the Princeton Tigers, entered his senior year at Princeton University in 2009, he began to realize that something was wrong in his body. He had headaches. He felt numbness in his limbs. He “couldn’t even walk up a set of stairs without getting tired,” he said. He got knocked down on the field and couldn’t get up.

headline: ‘If He Doesn’t Have That Stroke, He’s in the Hall of Fame’
text: J.R. Richard never faded. His next to last start was at the All-Star Game in 1980. He was 30 years old, at the apex of his powers, when it all went away. He was the Sandy Koufax of his generation.

headline: Their Careers and Romance Took Root in Politics
text: Henry Connelly, the communications director for the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, can relate to the cinematic tale of a farmer discovering his “Field of Dreams” in an Iowa cornfield.

headline: What to Do This Summer: Chapel Hill, N.C.
text: A liberal enclave in a right-leaning state, Chapel Hill, N.C., a hive of college activity during most months of the year, makes for a relaxed and entertaining summer getaway. The heat can be intense, but adopt the local habits of relaxing under ceiling fans and drinking plenty of ice-cold sweet tea, and you’ll be able to get the most out of the area’s many vibrant restaurants and cultural spots without breaking too much of a sweat.

headline: Biden Administration Is Still Struggling to Care for Migrant Children
text: At an emergency shelter in the Texas desert, migrant teenagers are housed in long, wide trailers, with little space for recreation and not much to do during the hot summer days, according to lawyers and other advocates for the children who have visited them there.

headline: No, the Unvaccinated Aren’t All Just Being Difficult
text: On a July day in downtown Lowell, Mass., the first sunny Saturday of the month, people began to line up for a block party. Food trucks offered everyone a free empanada or egg roll. A D.J. played music. There were kid-friendly activities, too, like a touch-a-truck station with a fire truck and an ambulance.

headline: Tucker Carlson Has a New Hero
text: Tucker Carlson is only the latest — and most famous — American conservative to find inspiration in the autocratic government of Hungary under Viktor Orban. The Fox News personality is hosting his show, one of the most popular on cable news, from the capital, Budapest, and on Saturday will deliver a speech, advertised as “The World According to Tucker Carlson,” to a conference of far-right activists.

headline: An Obstacle to Amtrak Expansion That Money Won’t Solve
text: WASHINGTON — More than a decade ago, Hurricane Katrina washed away many of the railroad tracks that line the Gulf Coast, leaving the region without a regular route to carry passengers.

headline: How a Daddy Longlegs Grows Such Strange Legs
text: The harvestman makes its way through the mossy woodland on eight spindly legs, delicate tentpoles supporting a plump body with two tiny eyes. These arachnids, sometimes called daddy longlegs, are cousins of spiders whose outdoorsy lifestyle sets them apart from the other creatures called daddy longlegs, which are more properly known as cellar spiders. They have other curious differences, too: The tips of a harvestman’s elegant limbs are flexible, allowing them to wrap around a twig like a monkey’s tail.

headline: The Mascot Whisperer
text: In America’s four major sports leagues, about nine out of every 10 teams have a mascot. As for the holdouts, they seem to believe that inanity has no place in their brands. The New York Yankees, who take corporate-management levels of pride in policing their players’ facial hair, are too self-consciously dignified for a mascot. The Los Angeles Lakers are too Hollywood for one, to the extent that they use Jack Nicholson instead.

headline: Hidden Bias in the Wedding Industrial Complex
text: Until it’s time to plan a major event like a wedding, there is little reason for most people to know about the existence of vendor lists: the directories of caterers, florists, event planners, D.J.s and others who work with venues to put on events.

headline: Together for Each Other in Sickness, Health and New Locks
text: Brittany Muszynski remembers the old saying about all brides being beautiful. But when her own wedding was approaching, she started doubting it. “I thought, ‘I’m going to feel so ugly when I get married,’” she said.

headline: How the Owner of a 24/7 Diner Spends Her Sundays
text: Three years ago, Irene Siderakis, a stay-at-home mom, suddenly inherited Kellogg’s Diner, a 24-hour go-to for eggs, burgers, nachos, Greek staples and more in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Chris Siderakis, her husband and the diner’s previous owner, had died unexpectedly, at 49. “I had no idea how to run a diner or if I could,” she said. “I had to make a choice: sell the diner or learn the business on my own and show my boys we can do this and persevere.” She opted for the latter.

headline: Hiroshi Sugimoto’s Jekyll and Hyde Year
text: Hiroshi Sugimoto laughs.

headline: New Jersey’s governor orders schools to use masks.
text: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey announced on Friday that in the face of the spreading, highly contagious Delta variant, all students, teachers, staff members and visitors would have to wear masks inside of school buildings when public schools open in a few weeks.

headline: Australian Man to Be Charged in Parliament House Rape Case
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Months after a former Australian government employee said she had been raped in Parliament House, the police announced on Friday that they intended to charge a man with sexual assault in the case.

headline: ‘There is nothing left’: After a town is wiped out, more of California is threatened.
text: After the Dixie Fire destroyed the Gold Rush town of Greenville, Calif., local officials said they were hopeful that improving weather conditions on Friday would help firefighters prevent the blaze from dealing further damage.

headline: Biting your own medal is one thing. A Japanese mayor learned you don’t bite someone else’s.
text: Olympic athletes have long been photographed biting their medals, a celebratory if not entirely hygienic gesture.

headline: The Challenges of Getting Employees Vaccinated
text: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: ‘The Da Vinci Code’ Writer’s Secret and What Female Athletes Wear: The Week in Narrated Articles
text: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Man Was Held for More Than 2 Years Over Mistaken Identity, His Lawyer Says
text: The long ordeal of Joshua Spriestersbach, a homeless man in Hawaii, began on May 11, 2017, when a Honolulu police officer woke him up and arrested him. He had fallen asleep as he waited in line to enter a shelter for food, but, instead, he was sent to a jail on Oahu for a crime he didn’t commit, according to a petition his lawyer filed this week seeking to clear his record.

headline: China says it will provide 2 billion vaccine doses to the world.
text: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, said the country would provide two billion Covid-19 vaccine doses to the world this year and would donate $100 million to a global effort to distribute the doses to developing countries, as Beijing attempts to take on a more prominent leadership role in curbing the pandemic.

headline: Voices of the Unvaccinated
text: With the Delta variant of the coronavirus raging across the United States, focus has turned to the millions of people in the country who have chosen not to be vaccinated against it.

headline: The pandemic has deepened global hunger, with poorer countries sinking deeper into crisis.
text: For years, global hunger has been steadily increasing as poor countries confront crises ranging from armed groups to extreme poverty. At the same time, climate-related droughts and floods have intensified, overwhelming the ability of affected countries to respond before the next disaster hits.

headline: A Push for Electric Vehicles
text: President Biden yesterday set an ambitious goal for the transition to electric vehicles: By 2030, half of all new vehicles sold in the U.S. should be electric.

headline: The leader of St. Vincent and the Grenadines is hurt during a protest against vaccine rules.
text: The prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines was hospitalized on Thursday after being struck in the head by a projectile during a protest against Covid vaccine legislation in the Caribbean island nation.

headline: Unvaccinated Americans explain their decisions.
text: With the Delta variant of the coronavirus raging across the United States, focus has turned to the millions of people in the country who have chosen not to accept a Covid shot.

headline: United Airlines will require vaccination, and Amazon revives mask mandates.
text: United Airlines said on Friday that it would require all U.S. employees to be vaccinated against the coronavirus starting this fall. It was the first major airline to establish such a mandate and the latest in a small but growing number of businesses to do so.

headline: How About Renting My Pool for an Hour or Two?
text: Have an amazing pool in your backyard? Or a secret garden? Or maybe a cabana with an outdoor fireplace? This could be the summer to cash in, as a handful of apps make it easier to rent the outdoors by the hour.

headline: The Labor Market’s Message
text: This morning, the government will report how many workers U.S. employers added to their payrolls in July. Economists expect a big number — as many as 850,000 — in another sign that the economic recovery continues.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 9: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
text: Update, Aug. 24: Winners from this week have been announced!

headline: Joshua Cheptegei of Uganda wins the men’s 5,000 meters.
text: Joshua Cheptegei of Uganda took the gold medal in the men’s 5,000, surviving a physical and tactical race to hold off Mohammed Ahmed of Canada and Paul Chelimo of the United States.

headline: Hezbollah Fires Rockets at Israel as Risk of Escalation Looms
text: JERUSALEM — Hezbollah, the Iran-backed Lebanese militant group, claimed responsibility for firing a volley of rockets over Israel’s northern frontier on Friday, the latest in a spate of tit-for-tat cross-border attacks that have ratcheted up regional tensions.

headline: Allyson Felix wins her 10th Olympic medal, tying an American record in her sport.
text: TOKYO — With nine Olympic medals (six golds and three silvers), Felix was already tied with the Jamaican sprinter Merlene Ottey as the most decorated female Olympian in track and field.

headline: Dramatizing the Chernobyl Disaster, for Its Survivors
text: CHERNOBYL, Ukraine — In April 1986, Alexander Rodnyansky was a young documentary filmmaker living in Kyiv. When the fourth reactor of the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Station exploded 60 miles north of the Ukrainian capital, most citizens of the Soviet Union were not informed. It took the government 18 days to share exactly what had happened, but Rodnyansky had been filming the disaster zone from the day after the catastrophe.

headline: Another Town Is Leveled by Flames
A Super Mario Bros. game sells for $2 million, another record for gaming collectibles.
text: A vintage Super Mario Bros. video game has sold for $2 million, a collectibles company announced Friday, breaking the record for the most expensive video game sale that was set just weeks ago.

headline: Bette Midler and Julianne Moore at the Top of the July Sales Charts
text: Bette Midler and Julianne Moore shared top billing in July among New York City’s real estate closings.

headline: College Tuition Insurance Gains Attention in Pandemic
text: With the new college year about to begin amid a resurgent pandemic, college tuition insurance is getting new attention.

headline: Student-Athletes Can Now Earn Money. Here Are the Pitfalls.
text: Sunisa Lee took home three Olympic medals — gold, silver and bronze — and, in the process, went from being little known outside the gymnastics world to a breakout star.

headline: Novavax says U.S. paused federal funding to make more of its yet-to-be-approved vaccine.
text: Novavax, the Maryland firm that won a $1.75 billion federal contract to develop and produce a coronavirus vaccine, said on Thursday that the federal government would not fund further production of its vaccine until the company resolves concerns of federal regulators about its work.

headline: Faith Kipyegon of Kenya wins the 1,500 meters.
text: TOKYO — Faith Kipyegon of Kenya defended her Olympic title in the women’s 1,500 meters, and in the process ended Sifan Hassan’s audacious bid for three gold medals at the Tokyo Games.

headline: Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, 84, Dies; Key Figure in Portugal Revolt
text: Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, a Portuguese Army officer who helped mastermind the almost bloodless military overthrow of his country’s dictatorship in 1974 and later served a prison sentence on charges of inciting terrorism, died on July 25 in a military hospital in Lisbon. He was 84.

headline: ‘It’s not the same as the fires we were used to’: What it’s like to fight more intense blazes.
text: California is seeing larger and more intense wildfires, putting those on the front lines at greater risk as they attempt to stop raging flames like those from the Dixie Fire that ripped through Greenville, Calif., this week.

headline: A Top-to-Bottom Renovation in SoHo
text: A “Million Dollar Listing” agent has his own new listing.

headline: ‘Million Dollar Listing’ Agent Has His Own New Listing
text: Steve Gold has met with countless buyers and sellers in his decade-plus career in real estate, some appearing alongside him on Bravo’s “Million Dollar Listing New York.” But his meeting with a SoHo loft owner two years ago was probably the most memorable for the agent/reality TV star.

headline: Jamaica wins the women’s 4x100-meter relay easily, while Italy stuns the men’s field.
text: The Jamaican women put an exclamation point on their domination of Olympic sprinting Friday night, winning the women’s 4x100 relay in a race whose outcome seemed predetermined from the start.

headline: Taliban Seize Afghan Provincial Capital Just Weeks Before Final U.S. Withdrawal
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban captured a regional hub city in western Afghanistan on Friday, officials said, the first provincial capital to fall to the insurgency since the Biden administration announced the full withdrawal of U.S. troops.

headline: This Is the Job Market We’ve Been Waiting For
text: America is getting back to work.

headline: Meet Polka-Dot Man and Other Characters From ‘The Suicide Squad’
text: Taking on a giant intergalactic world-conquering starfish might look like a job for Superman, but in “The Suicide Squad” it’s up to the D-list supervillains of Task Force X to save the day … or, more frequently, die trying.

headline: ‘Reservation Dogs’ Uses Humor, Not Magic, to Conjure Native Culture
text: In a dramatic moment of the “Reservation Dogs” pilot, a car with tinted windows rolls up on the Dogs, a crew of four teenage petty thieves living on a Native reservation in Oklahoma. In slow motion, the rival gang members inside lower the car windows, faces covered with balaclavas, and then aim their guns and open fire … with paintballs.

headline: New York Man Charged in Scooter Crash That Killed the Actress Lisa Banes
text: Two months after a scooter driver hit and killed Lisa Banes, an actress who appeared in more than 80 roles on television and in film, including the thriller “Gone Girl,” a New York man was arrested on Thursday in connection with the fatal collision.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Céline Gounder
text: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Céline Gounder. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: The Icelandic Saga That Keeps Rita Dove Coming Back for More
text: The former poet laureate Rita Dove, whose new collection is “Playlist for the Apocalypse,” loves the Icelandic saga “Grettir the Strong”: “Bleak, modernist stuff! And yet revisiting that litany of betrayals and cruelties never fails to stir my spirits.”

headline: Wildfires in Greece Blaze Destructive Path Across Country
text: A major blaze just north of Athens continued to burn in Greece forcing evacuations in the area and threatening historic sites. This comes as the area deals with major heat waves.

headline: Hundreds of Thousands of Bikers Expected in Sturgis Despite Delta Variant
text: Although most large events shut down last summer because of the coronavirus pandemic, the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally forged ahead, panicking health experts as nearly a half-million motorcycle enthusiasts descended on the Black Hills of South Dakota.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.

headline: Janja Garnbret of Slovenia wins in women’s sport climbing.
text: Even before the final scores were calculated, Slovenia’s Janja Garnbret, the best female sport climber in recent years, dropped her head into her hands and shed tears.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Good morning. Dorie Greenspan is in The Times this week with a marvelous column about her granddaughter’s first birthday and the little cakes — Baby Cakes (above), she calls them — she’s making to mark the occasion. They’ll be her granddaughter’s first experience with sugar. Big day!

headline: 5 Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
text: Before you get to any of this month’s selection of off-the-beaten-path science fiction, do watch the trailer for “Trump vs. the Illuminati.” The plot summary starts with “A Chinese clone of 45th U.S. president Donald J. Trump survives the Earth’s destruction,” and that is pretty much all you need to know.

headline: Famed Conductor, Citing Brain Tumor, Withdraws From Concerts
text: The renowned conductor Michael Tilson Thomas announced on Friday that he would withdraw from performances for the next several months as he recovers from surgery to treat a brain tumor.

headline: Andre Iguodala Plans to End His Career With Golden State
text: Andre Iguodala found himself in recent months in discussions with his few N.B.A. peers remaining, the ones who sculpted paralleling journeys, from being teenagers to experiencing parenthood, from playing for free in high school gyms to playing for millions in front of thousands.

headline: An Ode to Balloons
text: Gravity is overrated.

headline: Retreat, Christian Soldier
text: Could their flight from mainstream society be a harbinger for the nation?

text: The toxicity of the web is peanuts compared with Big Tech’s failure to remake the physical world.

headline: Cuomo Lawyers Hit Back as Aide Who Says He Groped Her Files Complaint
text: [New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo will resign after sexual harassment investigation.]

headline: The Weekender
text: The 25 most significant works of postwar architecture. Also in this edition: Cecily Strong’s new memoir, and how Lorde made a summer song.

headline: Dixie Fire Ravages California Towns
text: The Dixie Fire has ravaged parts of California for more than three weeks and engulfed entire towns. In Plumas County, the fire has leveled most of its historic downtown district.

headline: A Group of Orca Outcasts Is Now Dominating an Entire Sea
text: Killer whales that feast on seals and hunt in small packs are thriving while their widely beloved siblings are dying out.

headline: Wonking Out: What Vaccine Supply Tells Us About International Trade
text: This article is a wonky edition of Paul Krugman’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it.

headline: Blame the Bobos
text: The creative class was supposed to foster progressive values and economic growth.

headline: U.S. Drifts Back to the Pack in Olympic Medal Count
text: TOKYO — The Summer Games forced Olympians to prepare for dastardly heat and pandemic protocols that added stress and complicated the normal rigors of the run-up.

headline: Squander
text: "I’m still a magpie. If it glitters, I want it, no matter the cost." A poem by W. J. Herbert.

headline: Why Millennials Are So Obsessed With Dogs
text: The only thing getting me through my 30s is a cranky, agoraphobic chihuahua named Midge.

headline: The Radical Feminism of a 17th-Century Priest
text: François Poulain attacked the patriarchy and considered the work of motherhood to be as worthy of respect as any other form of labor.

headline: Sneaky Thieves Steal Hair From Foxes, Raccoons, Dogs, Even You
text: As anyone who has ever tried to eat french fries on a beach will attest, stealing is not an uncommon behavior among birds. In fact, many birds are quite skilled at bold and brazen theft.

headline: Amazon Wins Court Battle in India Against a Local Powerhouse
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court on Friday ruled in favor of Amazon’s bid to block a multibillion-dollar deal that would give the country’s richest man control over an Indian supermarket chain, in a boost to the American retailing giant’s ambitions toward India’s nearly $900 billion retail market.

headline: The Weeknd’s Disco Fever, and 9 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

text: THE LAST CUENTISTABy Donna Barba Higuera

headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Season 2 Episode 3 Recap: Youth in Revolt
text: This week, “Ted Lasso” begins with perhaps the most sinister of American sitcom tropes: the introduction of a precocious, world-wise 13-year-old.

headline: Business as Unusual

headline: ‘One of You Is a Monster’
text: It took more than a decade, but David Peace has finally published TOKYO REDUX (Knopf, 464 pp., $28), the final volume of one of my favorite crime trilogies. There are no duds in Peace’s body of work: The “Red Riding” quartet depicts the despair and horror of living in proximity to the Yorkshire Ripper murders, while a looser trio of novels (“GB84,” “The Damned Utd” and “Red or Dead”) offers wily social commentary on what ailed and uplifted postwar northern England, sometimes simultaneously.

headline: What’s Going On With Extreme Weather?
text: Here's what you should know about extreme weather events like heat waves, droughts and storms.

headline: It’s Not Just the Medal. It’s the Payout.
text: TOKYO — After winning a gold medal at the Summer Olympics here, the U.S. wrestler Tamyra Mensah-Stock had big plans for the bonus money that comes with it: buying her mother a $30,000 food truck.

headline: Push to Return 116,000 Native American Remains Is Long-Awaited
text: In 1990, when Congress passed a law that set criteria under which federally recognized Native American tribes could reclaim ancient burial remains and sacred objects, legislators hoped to encourage the return of items by museums and other institutions. But more than three decades later, some officials acknowledge that the law, known as the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act, or NAGPRA, has not been as effective as they had hoped.

headline: Charged With Treason, a Genocide Survivor Opts to Fight, Not Flee
text: BANGKOK — Only a small child when the Khmer Rouge seized power in 1975 and soon made her an orphan, Theary Seng has two enduring memories from that time in Cambodia’s tortured history.

headline: The Dixie Fire is now the largest blaze in the U.S., and third-largest wildfire on record in California.
text: The Dixie Fire exploded by more than 97,000 acres in 24 hours, becoming the third-largest wildfire on record in California by Friday. It had been only sixth on the list of blazes the day before.

headline: A Remarkable Almond Cake Made Even Better
text: A testament to a well-loved recipe is that, when you pull the cookbook it’s in off the shelf, it automatically falls open to that page. And that’s exactly what happens whenever I reach for “Chez Panisse Desserts” by Lindsey Shere. The sticky pages of the almond torte recipe fling themselves upward, willing me to bake it, even if I had another sweet in mind.

headline: The Barn
text: In 1955, just past daybreak, a Chevrolet truck pulled up to an unmarked building. A 14-year-old child named Emmett Till was in the back.

headline: The Delta Variant Surges in the U.S.
text: The latest news and data from the team tracking the coronavirus.

headline: Canada beats Sweden in a shootout for the women’s soccer gold medal.
text: Canada, a relentless team with an aging star, a sturdy defense and a taste for more after consecutive bronze medals, won its first gold medal in women’s soccer on Friday by defeating Sweden in a penalty shootout, 3-2, after a 1-1 tie in Yokohama.

headline: What Does Mitch McConnell Do Now?
text: At age 79, the longtime Senate Republican leader is contemplating his legacy.

text: Kanye held a listening party for thousands of fans in Atlanta.

headline: Love Letter: Married to a Worrier
text: Even if you’re not usually an anxious person, it’s common to feel worry, doubt and even fear in times of uncertainty. However, excessive worrying can often drive a wedge between you and your loved ones.

headline: A Volcano, a Fishing Boat, and a Narrow Escape
text: Two government biologists barely made it off a remote Alaskan island alive. No one had known it was ready to erupt.

headline: Uncovering the Cultural Revolution’s Awful Truths
text: Rebel historians chronicle a past that the Chinese Communist Party grows ever more intent on erasing.

headline: After Deadly Floods, a German Village Rethinks Its Relationship to Nature
text: RECH, Germany — Shortly before midnight Dominik Gieler received one last WhatsApp message from his mother. She had watched as a tsunami of river first took one, then two, then all of the houses around her own. “I won’t make it out of here,” she told him.

headline: The Second Career of Martellus Bennett
text: The former NFL tight end writes the kind of children’s books he would have loved as a kid.

headline: The COVID-19 Manhattan Project
text: Never have so many researchers trained their minds on a single problem in so brief a time. Science will never be the same.

headline: Senators pause for a funeral before weekend votes on infrastructure.
text: Presidencies are governed by events and priorities, and President Biden — propelled into office by epochal events in 2020 — has staked his political fortunes on passage of a $1 trillion infrastructure bill intended to demonstrate his competence, can-do attitude and commitment to bipartisanship.

headline: Tokyo Olympics on Friday: Delivering in the Heat
text: The U.S. women’s beach volleyball team won gold in some of the hottest temperatures at these Games.

headline: California and Hawaii step up pressure on workers to be vaccinated.
text: California ordered all health care workers to get their shots, largely removing an option to be tested. Hawaii is requiring state and county employees to be vaccinated or face weekly testing.

headline: How Do I Know if I Have Adult A.D.H.D.?
text: A: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., is a neurodevelopmental disorder often characterized by inattention, disorganization, hyperactivity and impulsivity.

text: The stands may have been almost empty at the Tokyo Games, but these performances deserve to be seen. Here is what the Summer Olympics looked like from up close.

text: Revisiting the most disturbing Christmas special.

headline: Why Aren’t People Going Back to Their Jobs?
text: This week, our team talked to a lot of hesitant people. We heard from those who were skeptical of getting vaccinated about their decision making this morning. And for Tuesday’s episode, we spoke with both employers and prospective employees across the country to get a better sense of why so many Americans are reluctant to return to work.

headline: How do wildfires get their names?
text: Dixie. August Complex. Not Creative.

headline: ‘Evangelion’ Director Explains How He Finally Found His Ending
text: Finally.

headline: There's No Stopping Santa
text: The middle of a global pandemic might seem like a good time to cut back on holiday excess. But then, we live in America.

headline: Tokyo Was Promised Glory and Riches. It Got an Olympics in a Bubble.
text: TOKYO — Tokyo’s leaders promised glory and riches when the Japanese capital won its bid to host the 2020 Summer Olympics. Jobs and the economy would grow. The public would rally in support. Japan’s international stature would rise.

headline: Whitewashing the Great Depression
text: How the preeminent photographic record of the period eclipsed people of color and shaped the nation’s self-image.

headline: Can the Olympics Take the Heat?
text: Maybe every athlete went into the Tokyo Olympics secretly worried that they hadn’t prepared sufficiently for the challenge. I know I did. Would my performance be affected by the 13-hour time difference? Could I handle the long hours in front of a screen while juggling my beer and ice cream?

headline: JPMorgan’s punishment for currency rigging ends.
text: The Federal Reserve has lifted restrictions on JPMorgan Chase for its role in rigging foreign exchange rates between 2008 to 2013.

headline: Kanye West Fans Turn Up at Donda Show ‘to See History Unfold’
text: ATLANTA — For the mile leading up to Mercedes-Benz Stadium, which these days might be better known as Kanye West’s new home, cars crawled along MLK Jr. Drive. Thousands of fans were on the way to listen to “Donda,” his long awaited 10th album. “Kanye got that downtown traffic jammin,” one local tweeted.

headline: The First Play Returning to Broadway Is Doing Things Differently
text: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Don’t Be Fooled by Mitch McConnell’s Sudden Bout of Bipartisanship
text: Are we entering a new era of bipartisanship? On the surface, the news from Washington seems remarkably encouraging. The Senate is close to passing a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill, with $550 billion in new spending on everything from transit to highways to broadband to climate change mitigation. Political insiders are hailing the bill as a breakthrough, with the Senate poised, at last, to overcome the partisan gridlock that has ground its legislative machinery to a halt. Many thought that President Biden’s belief that he could get Republican votes was naïve, but he delivered. In a surprise, even the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, voted to move the compromise to a vote.

headline: Why Biden Will (Probably) Keep This Republican on His Team
text: Many of the most powerful people in Washington and New York are talking about the most important economic policy job in America, the leadership of the Federal Reserve. The chair of our nation’s central bank is appointed by the president for a four-year term. In 2018 the current chair, Jerome Powell, was appointed by President Donald Trump. So his position is up for renewal in 2022, which is naturally leading people to wonder whether President Biden will reappoint Mr. Powell.

headline: What We Are Not Teaching Boys About Being Human
text: A while back, at the bookstore with my three sons, I started flicking through a kids’ magazine that had the kind of hyper-pink sparkly cover that screams: “Boys! Even glancing in this direction will threaten your masculinity!”

headline: Our Families Fought for Civil Rights. Don’t Let Jim Crow Stand.
text: I’m Myrlie Evers. Right before he was murdered, my husband, Medgar Evers, told me, “Don’t ever give up on those things that you believe in.” Medgar and I had a transcendent connection, and these words have lifted my spirits throughout the decades-long fight for justice against Medgar’s assassin, my time at the N.A.A.C.P. and my run for Congress against a far-right extremist. Now, those words guide me whenever I see things Medgar fought and died for being erased by misguided politicians.

headline: Italians (Mostly) Embrace a ‘Green Pass’ to Prove Vaccination on Its First Day
text: ORBETELLO, Italy — On Friday, the first day that Italians needed to present a nationwide health passport for access to indoor dining, museums, gyms, theaters and a wide range of social activities, Margherita Catenuto, 18, from Sicily, proudly showed a bar code at the Capitoline Museum in Rome certifying that she was vaccinated.

headline: F.D.A. Aiming to Speed Extra Vaccine Doses for Immunocompromised Patients
text: The Food and Drug Administration is speeding efforts to authorize extra doses of the coronavirus vaccines for Americans with weakened immune systems, a change that reflects a growing concern within the Biden administration about these vulnerable patients as the contagious Delta variant surges nationwide.

headline: New data suggest J. & J. vaccine works against Delta and recipients don’t need a booster shot.
text: A single dose of the Covid-19 vaccine made by Johnson & Johnson is highly effective in preventing severe illness and death from the Delta and Beta variants of the coronavirus, data from a clinical trial in South Africa suggest.

headline: Why Do We Make Things So Hard for Renters?
text: For struggling homeowners in the pandemic’s first year, there was hope early on that these hard times would not put people with mortgages out in the street.

headline: Our Culture of Winning at All Costs Is Broken. It Almost Broke Me.
text: “Little girl, slow down!” a startled member of the ski patrol yelled after me as I sped past him and sailed down the hill.

headline: Your Next Lesson: White Wine Blends
text: Red blends are popular right now, and I’m not speaking of classical blends like Bordeaux, Châteauneuf-du-Pape or Chianti.

headline: A Rosé by Any Other Color
text: The color of a wine can convey a lot about its character. But color is easy to misinterpret, and sometimes reveals less than it seems.

headline: Katie Kitamura Talks About ‘Intimacies’
text: The slightly directionless, unnamed narrator of Katie Kitamura’s fourth novel, “Intimacies,” takes a job as a translator at an international criminal court. On this week’s podcast, Kitamura talks about the novel, including her realization about the book’s title.

headline: Udo Kier’s Latest Provocation: Leading Man
text: In 1966, a pouty-mouthed Udo Kier made his movie debut in a zippy short called “Road to Saint Tropez,” playing a gigolo who has a fling with an older woman. Their day at Baie des Anges is a romp, but by the time they get to the film’s title beach town, he breaks her heart.

headline: Reconsidering Outdoor Travel in the West, as Wildfires Burn
text: Part of what Katherine Lee loves about Moscow, Idaho, where she lives, are the trails 10 minutes away. She visits with family or friends several days a week to hike or mountain bike, or to have walking meetings with colleagues.

headline: An Arkansas judge temporarily blocks the state’s ban on mask mandates.
text: A judge in Arkansas on Friday temporarily blocked a ban on mask mandates, which will allow school districts and other government entities in the state to require face coverings to help curb the spread of new coronavirus infections.

headline: Herbert Schlosser, a Force Behind ‘S.N.L.’ and ‘Laugh-In,’ Dies at 95
text: Herbert Schlosser, a longtime NBC executive who put an indelible stamp on the network by negotiating Johnny Carson’s first deal to host “The Tonight Show,” putting “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In” on the air and overseeing the development of “Saturday Night Live,” died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Relief and Redemption as U.S. Women’s Volleyball Team Will Play for Gold
text: TOKYO — The morning of the Olympic women’s volleyball semifinal on Friday here at the Tokyo Games, Foluke Akinradewo, a three-time Olympian and middle blocker for the U.S. team, had a premonition: the United States was going to have a perfect match.

headline: Allyson Felix Has Joy, and a 10th Olympic Medal
text: TOKYO — Allyson Felix stayed on the track for a long time on Friday night after finishing the 400-meter race.

headline: What Is Going on With Obama’s 60th Birthday Bash?
text: Jay-Z and Beyoncé were still in, as of Friday.

headline: Here’s what happened in Tokyo on Friday.
text: TOKYO — On the track Friday night, Shaunae Miller-Uibo of the Bahamas powered away from the field in the 400 meters, while Allyson Felix, in third place, won a record 10th Olympic medal.

headline: Wildfires Rage Across Turkey
text: Turkish authorities ordered mass evacuations as fire crews and volunteers battled more than 180 wildfires across the country amid one of the region’s worst heatwaves in decades.

headline: Canada’s Drought Is Forcing Farmers to Make Once-Unthinkable Choices
text: We’re halfway through the summer and since the beginning of the season, the effects of extreme weather in Western Canada have been relentless. The devastation in British Columbia and the Prairies, including raging wildfires and extreme drought, are threatening lives and livelihoods.

headline: Biden administration extends a student loan payment pause.
text: WASHINGTON — The Education Department announced Friday that it would continue a moratorium on federal student loan payments through Jan. 31, extending emergency relief for millions of borrowers that had been set to expire next month.

headline: Patricia Wilde, Ballerina Showcased by Balanchine, Dies at 93
text: Patricia Wilde, a principal dancer known for her speed and daring as a member of George Balanchine’s New York City Ballet in its early years, and later an influential teacher and artistic director, died on July 17 in Stephens City, Va. She was 93.

headline: Vaccine reduces risk of infection even in people who have already had Covid, the C.D.C. says.
text: Unvaccinated people who have had Covid-19 may be more than twice as likely to get infected again than those who tested positive and bolstered their natural immunity with a vaccine, according to a small study that assessed the likelihood of reinfection.

headline: Conor Lamb Gets In, and a Crucial Senate Fight Takes Shape in Pennsylvania
text: PITTSBURGH — Representative Conor Lamb thinks he knows what it takes for Democrats to win statewide in Pennsylvania.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Welcome. When friends ask how it’s going, these days, what do you tell them?

headline: The Gloriously Versatile Plantain
text: Starches — legumes, tubers, grains, to name a few — are a motley bunch. But one thing they share is how they strike a delicate balance between firm and plump, and, well, dried out or mealy when cooked. One starch, though, is sturdy enough to withstand a little overcooking and can be prepared at any stage of ripeness: the gloriously versatile plantain.

headline: A Labor Leader Is Gone, and the Road Ahead for Unions Is Steep
text: In many ways, A.F.L.-C.I.O. President Richard Trumka, who died of a heart attack on Thursday, was an old-line union leader. His grandfather and father were coal miners. And he, too, worked in the mines before going to law school. He once led one of the nation’s oldest and most tradition-bound unions, the United Mine Workers. He had another old-line attribute — he was a truculent fighter who didn’t give up easily, once leading a ten-month strike by 1,700 miners against Pittston Coal.

headline: What to Watch: Music Documentaries
text: From a trip to church with Aretha Franklin to a glimpse of hell at an ill-fated Rolling Stones concert, here are five nonfiction films that are worth a look and a listen.

headline: New Jersey Will Require Masks in Schools
text: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey announced that due to the rapid spread of the Delta variant, all students, teachers and staff members would be required to wear masks at the start of the school year.

headline: The Timeless Appeal of Tommie Smith, Who Knew a Podium Could Be a Site of Protest
text: THE STREET VENDORS along 125th Street in Harlem sell all manner of things: perfume and watches, shea butter and cellphone accessories, paperback books and, of course, T-shirts. One memorable shirt shows three athletes on the medal stand: a white man looking straight ahead and two Black men with heads bowed and arms outstretched, their black-gloved fists raised high in the air. It’s a familiar image, even 53 years after the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City, at which the American sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos staged one of the most iconic protests of the last century.

headline: Jobs, Vaccines, Team Mascots: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Chris Cuomo is taking a birthday week vacation as scrutiny on his brother increases.
text: Chris Cuomo is set to begin a weeklong vacation from his prime-time CNN talk show on Friday, a break that the host described as a previously scheduled absence planned around his birthday.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: The F.D.A. is accelerating efforts to authorize extra doses of the coronavirus vaccines for immunocompromised Americans. Experts say it’s a safer alternative than patients seeking shots on their own, as many now do.

headline: What Exactly Is Modern Pentathlon?
text: The women's modern pentathlon took place Friday. Here's what you need to know

headline: A Pyrrhic Victory in a Broken Senate
text: Around the time of the enactment of the American Rescue Plan Act, in March, the political commentariat devoted a lot of airtime and column inches to a telling question: What lessons had President Biden and the Democratic Party learned from the Obama era? Congressional Democrats passed the relief bill on a party-line vote. Watering it down to achieve bipartisan support would have been a “mistake,” Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, said at the time, one that Democrats would not be making again. The administration had only so much time, after all, to try to pass the most pro-worker labor reforms in a generation or to put an end to congressional malapportionment.

headline: ‘We lost everything’: Residents are left in shock by the Dixie Fire’s destruction.
text: QUINCY, Calif. — A day after wind-driven flames from the Dixie Fire ripped through the Northern California town of Greenville, residents who had reluctantly left their homes behind sat at a picnic table under hazy skies in a parking lot about 25 miles away.

headline: As Senate Vote Nears for $1 Trillion Infrastructure Bill, Deficit Takes a Back Seat
text: WASHINGTON — The bipartisan shrug that greeted the news that the Senate’s infrastructure bill contains $256 billion worth of deficit spending marked a new moment in the post-Trump era, one that highlighted how deficits matter only situationally to Republicans and inflation fears ebb and flow, depending on the politics of the issue.

headline: Ilona Royce Smithkin, Improbable Muse in Fashion and Art, Dies at 101
text: Ilona Royce Smithkin, who as an orange-haired nonagenarian with matching two-inch eyelashes caught fire in the world of fashion, starring in a documentary film and joining fashion campaigns for brands like Coach, while flinging embers into many other fields as a muse for photographers, filmmakers and entertainers — a joyous persona that took a lifetime to build after a grim childhood — died on Aug. 1 at her home in Provincetown, Mass. She was 101.

headline: Russia Doesn’t Send U.S. Investor to Jail but Still Sends a Warning
text: MOSCOW — A Russian court sentenced on Friday an American businessman who is one of the country’s most prominent foreign investors to a suspended sentence of five-and-a-half years in a penal colony for a conviction on embezzlement charges, in a ruling that could hurt Russia’s ability to attract foreign investment.

headline: Barry the Owl, Beloved by N.Y.C. Birders, Dies in Central Park Collision
text: Barry the Barred Owl, whose majestic presence and unusually extroverted demeanor made her a beloved Central Park celebrity, died early Friday in a collision with a Central Park Conservancy maintenance vehicle.

headline: Paul Cotton, Mainstay of the Country-Rock Band Poco, Dies at 78
text: Paul Cotton, the lead guitarist and frequent lead singer and songwriter for the country-rock band Poco, died on July 31 near his summer home in Eugene, Ore. He was 78.

headline: As Covid Surges in Florida, DeSantis Refuses to Change Course
text: MIAMI — Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida snapped this week at a reporter who asked if masks might help keep children safe in a state that now has more Covid-19 hospitalizations, including for pediatric patients, than anywhere else in the nation.

headline: A British BMX racer’s historic gold required a little financial help from her friends.
text: When Bethany Shriever secured the gold medal in the women’s BMX racing final, it was in an event in which she was not even projected to be a finalist. The win last week was Britain’s first Olympic gold in the event.

headline: Democrats Eye Budget to Force Policy Changes, Testing Bounds of the Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Congress plan to use their $3.5 trillion budget to try to unilaterally speed through a suite of far-reaching policy changes on immigration, labor and possibly voting rights over Republican opposition, leveraging their slim majorities in a bid to achieve much of President Biden’s agenda in one fell swoop.

headline: Myanmar Ambassador, Who Opposed Coup, Is Target of Assassination Plot
text: Two Myanmar citizens living in New York plotted over the past month to attack and potentially kill the country’s ambassador to the United Nations who resides in Westchester County, federal prosecutors in Manhattan said on Friday.

headline: Britney Spears’s Father Fights Effort to Remove Him as Conservator
text: One day after a lawyer for Britney Spears asked the court to expedite the hearing on whether to remove her father from the conservatorship that has long ruled her life, the singer’s father defended his actions over the past 13 years in a court filing.

headline: Jon Lindbergh, Aviator’s Son Who Took to the Sea, Dies at 88
text: Jon Lindbergh, an acclaimed deep-sea diver and underwater demolition expert whose life as the son of Col. Charles A. Lindbergh was shaped by the height of fame and the depths of tragedy that his family experienced, died on July 29 at his home in Lewisburg, W.Va. He was 88.

headline: The United States and France battle for the gold medal in men’s basketball.
text: TOKYO — The men’s basketball tournament at the Tokyo Olympics comes to a close on Saturday with the gold medal game between the United States and France in the morning (on NBC; follow our live coverage), and a third-place matchup between Australia and Slovenia later in the day (7 a.m. Eastern on USA).

headline: The Olympic Marathon in Sapporo: A Test of Survival
text: Peres Jepchirchir, 27, of Kenya won the women’s Olympic marathon in 2 hours 27 minutes 20 seconds on Saturday in Sapporo, Japan, 500 miles north of Tokyo, where officials moved the 26.2-mile race in a preventive but futile attempt to escape the heat and humidity that have smothered the Summer Games.

headline: Decisive Moments From the Tokyo Games, Frame by Frame
text: See the Summer Olympics in a series of composite images.

headline: U.S. Businessman Responds to Sentencing in Russia
text: Michael Calvey, an American businessman working in Russia who had been convicted on embezzlement charges, maintained he was innocent and called the conviction “simply outrageous” after he was given a suspended sentence of five and a half years.

headline: Bit of Deception
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I had a tough time finding a way into Adam Aaronson’s benignly fiendish Saturday puzzle. Some constructors, and Mr. Aaronson seems to be one of them, excel at writing clues that have the precision necessary for the right answer to click smartly into place when it is entered, yet are just vague enough to have seven or 12 or 29 of those potential right answers. Frustrating? Yup. Fun? Totally. Slow? Exceptionally, but maybe that’s just me. Rewarding? Very much so. As I filled in and deleted and filled in and deleted (happily, I wasn’t tethered to a pen or pencil) some almost-poetic patterns revealed themselves.

headline: Here’s how to watch the game in the United States.
text: The United States and France play at Saitama Super Arena at 11:30 a.m. Saturday in Tokyo, which is 13 hours ahead of Eastern time.

headline: Paris 2024 Presses On With Plan A, but Studies Tokyo’s Plan B
text: TOKYO — Tony Estanguet wants to talk about how the next Olympic Games, in Paris in 2024, will be a paradigm-shifting moment for an event that has come under fire for becoming too bloated, too costly, too onerous for the citizens of the places where the quadrennial sporting jamboree lands.

headline: U.S. broadcast highlights on Saturday morning include gold medal games in baseball and soccer.
text: The next-to-last day of the Tokyo Olympics wraps up on Saturday with the gold medal contest in men’s soccer and additional gold to be awarded in women’s golf, men’s volleyball and beach volleyball, men’s platform diving, women’s water polo and much more. All times are Eastern and are subject to network changes.

headline: Welcome to the Kevin Durant and Jayson Tatum show.
text: It goes without saying, but having Kevin Durant on your team is a very nice luxury.

headline: The United States closed out its run to win gold — its fourth in a row.
text: SAITAMA, Japan — It was not always pretty, but in the end, the United States men’s basketball team ascended to the heights they were always expected to reach. Overcoming a slow start to the Olympic tournament, the Americans dispatched France, 87-82, with relative comfort in the final game on Saturday morning at Saitama Super Arena to win their 16th gold medal in the event.

headline: Japan gets its first baseball gold, a highlight for the host country.
text: YOKOHAMA, Japan — Back after a 13-year absence from the Olympics, the baseball gold medal came down to a showdown between the two biggest baseball countries in the world: the United States and Japan.

headline: Nelly Korda of the U.S. captures the gold in women’s golf.
text: Nelly Korda of the United States held off a final-round challenge from Japan’s Mone Inami and New Zealand’s Lydia Ko to claim the gold medal in women’s golf at Kasumigaseki Country Club.

headline: Conservative Fellow Travelers: Tucker Carlson Drops In On Viktor Orban
text: BUDAPEST — It’s been a meeting of conservative fellow travelers: a jovial host — who heads an authoritarian government bent on targeting liberal institutions, including universities, the judiciary and the media — and his American guest exchanging grins.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.

headline: Behind Durant, U.S. Men’s Basketball Finds Path to Olympic Gold
text: SAITAMA, Japan — Gregg Popovich, the head coach of the United States men’s basketball team, exhaled on Saturday afternoon as he contemplated his team’s 87-82 victory over France to win an Olympic gold medal.

headline: U.S. women’s water polo wins its third straight gold medal.
text: TOKYO — The U.S. women’s water polo team won its third consecutive Olympic gold medal on Saturday, routing Spain, 14-5.

headline: Dressel vs. Phelps. McLaughlin vs. Muhammad. Visualizing Olympic Champions, Present vs. Past
text: See how the fastest swimmers and runners from Tokyo 2020 compare with past champions, plus watch visualizations of more than 40 Olympic races.

headline: America’s Dismal Foreign Policy — and What to Do About It
